newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria agency sees rate fall to 30 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria agency sees rate fall to 30 pct in 1997.

text.p: Bulgaria's Agency for Economic Forecast and Development expects annual interest rates to fall to 30 percent after the introduction of a currency board, the agency's director Gancho Ganchev said on Wednesday.

"Our forecast is that annual interest rate next year will average around 30 percent," Ganchev, who is also deputy minister of economic development, told a news conference. The central bank's main interest rate is currently 180 percent.
The rate is expected to slide gradually and hit low levels by the end on a one-year operation of the currency board, said Ganchev.

Bulgaria's central bank raised the main interest rate to a record high of 300 percent annually in September in a bid to support the collapsing lev by curbing panic withdrawals of savings and their conversion into dollars.
The lev's chronic instability prevented the central bank from reducing the rate lower than 180 percent in the past two months.
Bulgaria is now discussing the introduction of a tough currency board regime proposed by the International Monetary Fund to boost confidence in the crumbling financial system.
Under the system, the central bank will not be able to print levs it cannot cover with hard currency reserves, which is expected to remove political pressure from monetary policy.
The bank will also be banned from lending to the government and commercial banks.
"With restricted or banned refinancing of commercial banks by the central bank, the current interest rate structure will change under a currency board system," said Ganchev.
The main interest rate set by central bank will be replaced by different rate levels -- the interbank market rate, the lending rate of commercial banks and the deposit rate, said Ganchev.
Interest on deposits will be lower than the market and lending rates, said Ganchev.
Currently the market rate is several points higher than the main interest rate and the rate on deposits is up to 10 percent lower.
Annual inflation next year is seen at between 20 and 30 percent, depending at what rate the lev will be pegged, said Ganchev.
"It will be best to fix the rate at the market rate of the day the currency baord is launched," said Ganchev.
The lev traded at around 450 to the dollar on Wednesday, down from 70 in the beginning of the year.
The agency predicted economic growth at zero next year. The Economy Institute of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences expected an eight percent decline of the economy.
"It (growth) depends very much on when the currency board plan is introduced," said Ganchev.
The system will be introduced after the parliament passes next year's budget and a package of legal amendments which would make the currency board operational.
The cabinet has not approved the 1997 draft budget so far, but officials said that the budget frame is based on assumptions of the agency.
-- Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-84561
